text: finally, a model that hurts your feelings
title: opus 4.6

text: work is quite fun now, but hyperventilating at the terminal all day does not feel like an equilibrium. i hope that in the future, maybe soon, i can move slow and focus deeply again
title: 100 year mental health break

text:
after i drink coffee in the morning, if i don't immediately start working, i have ideas and start penning little essays in my head

these start as drafts of twitter posts. but i never post them, for two reasons i think: (1) too many people follow me, and some of these people are impressive, and i don't want to show half-baked / poorly written thoughts to these people; (2) i have trouble being sincere online

but i would still like a place to post unpolished thoughts

if it's not public, then i don't find it exciting, and i won't write things down

so here we are
title: meta

text:
one way san francisco is different from new york is that you can sit down in a cafe and it doesnt feel like you're getting away with something

stepping outside in new york is war. in sf it's just getting breakfast

taking the bart from sf to berkeley was quite simple, but i was surprised how much it cost

chatted with a random guy waiting for the next pick up game at ymca. he was a swe intern. he brought up "tech twitter" within 3 turns of conversation

surprised how some parts resembled any other city
title: sf
nba tanking
text:
its remarkable that nba lottery system has been around this long without things getting _that_ bad

under certain conditions, teams are rewarded for losing games. of course they will intentionally lose games! incentives are broken

its more fundamental than that though. teams are only indirectly rewarded for winning games through better tv deals, demand for games, merchandise sales. i wager team revenue increasingly decouples from winning games over time because of celebrity players

this might happen with lebron's final season, has arguably already happened with lebron on the lakers. his farewell tour will do crazy ticket sales, and he will be probably a ~0 VORP player, but wouldn't be surprised if teams would trade substantial assets to grab the revenue.

eventually there will be a larger reckoning similar about misaligned incentives. nba will have a choice then: have teams participate in revenue sharing, or become a pure entertainment league a la savannah bananas. 50/50 either way i think.

im cautiously optimistic nba will do team revenue sharing (s.t. teams are rewarded for winning games, playoff performance) because of gambling partnerships and money prize for nba cup. seems like nba has broken through a lot of the taboos around money/competing for money/financial incentives for people who are already rich
